text: Emily Howell Warner (October 30, 1939 – July 3, 2020) was an American airline pilot. She the first woman captain of a scheduled US airline. She was born in Denver, Colorado. In 1973, Warner was the first woman pilot to be hired by a scheduled US airline since Helen Richey was hired as a co-pilot in 1934. In 1976 Warner was the first woman to become a US airline captain. == Biography == She was honored into the National Aviation Hall of Fame and National Women’s Hall of Fame. Her pilot’s uniform is on display at the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum. She is the first woman who has been a member of the Air Line Pilots Association (ALPA). Warner was a flight school manager in Denver, Colorado. She flew more than 21,000 flight hours and performed more than 3,000 check rides and evaluations over her career. Warner died in 2020 from problems caused by a fall and Alzheimer's disease in Littleton, Colorado at the age of 80. ==References== Category:1939 births Category:2020 deaths Category:American aviators Category:Educators from Denver Category:Accidental deaths from falls in the United States Category:Deaths from Alzheimer's disease
